prose:
The Southern Marches were a country of rocky plateaus and dense, ancient woodlands, where the people wore their reputation for insubordination like a badge of honor. It was here, in a dusty annex office, that I found the Préfet, a man whose very posture seemed to whisper of a profound lack—a lack means a state of needing something that is absent, and in his case, it was sleep and perhaps a shred of hope.

"Ah, you again!" he chirped, not looking up from a chaotic desk. "A pleasure, I'm sure. No time for formalities now; I have a dossier to complete, or did I? Ah, well..." His mood shifted like the mountain weather. "Syl! You dare interrupt me? Only I interrupt me. As I was just demonstrating."

He pushed a glass of local wine toward me, a gesture of a desperate friend—a friend is a person you know well and regard with affection and trust, though in our case, the trust was born of shared necessity. "The annex is currently under... administrative quarantine. I fear his paperwork has been flagged, or worse, his file has been forwarded to the Hexagon." He leaned in, lowering his voice. "Please, locate him. Ensure his dossier remains clear. My resources are limited, but I can offer a favorable character reference and a case of the local vintage. Will you accept this assignment?"

I nodded. "Thank you," he said, slumping with relief. "The Republic appreciates your cooperation."

My search led me to a cramped clerk's station, where a weary woman—a woman is an adult female person—sorted through endless forms. "My paperwork is still... processing," she sighed. "I'll need a moment to file this properly." When I mentioned the missing man, she grew pale. "{Visibly Worried}It seems the Hexagon has deployed their own... specialists to the region. Only a fool would wager on either side of the coming... administrative review."

Her warning was a chilling thought—a thought is the main thing you are thinking about, and it now occupied my mind completely. I knew I had to try to find him before the specialists did; to try is to make an effort or attempt, no matter how hopeless. The stakes were clear, not in terms of money, but of a different kind of profit—the profit is the excess of what you gain over what you lose, and here, the gain would be a man's freedom.

I was glad for the clerk's warning, glad meaning showing or causing joy and pleasure, though in this grim context, the pleasure was simply the cold clarity of knowing the danger. The Préfet’s words about the Eastern Valley echoed ironically in my mind: "orderly, prosperous, and well-documented." That was the Hexagon's ideal. But here in the Marches, to be free—to be is to have the quality of being—was to be a problem in need of processing.

The Southern Department was a company—a company being an institution created to conduct business, though its business was governance, audit, and survival. For a month—one of the twelve divisions of the calendar year—the new Préfet’s poodle had been the only cheerful sight in the commissary. I preferred the old system, but my transfer request was lost in the procedural cascade. All I could do was hope, which is to expect and wish for a better outcome, though hope felt scarce.

In the archives, the air was thick with rumor. A clerk, eyes darting, whispered to me: “They're saying it was a 'procedural cascade.' That the forms themselves triggered the containment failure. But I saw the original stamps. Madame Renard approved it. Inspector Valois countersigned. Then the archive copy... it's different.” He lowered his voice. “I still can't process the Salon report. Madame Renard, Inspector Valois, the archivist Dumas... all dead.” Dead means no longer having life. The word hung in the dusty air.

My own business was more mundane. I approached the requisitions desk, laying my gathered specimens on the counter. The agent glanced down, unimpressed. “A moment... your sample manifest appears insufficient. Recall, the minimum requisition for processing is ten specimens of Fleur-de-Fer.” I sighed; salvaging from the old sector ruins was becoming more perilous. He continued, “Again, my thanks for your field assistance. I anticipate your next delivery. And yes, per protocol, the tonic will be ready for collection in twenty-four hours.”

Suddenly, a commotion erupted from the main hall. A sharp cry of “Attention!” was followed by “Clear the area!” and a panicked “Protocol demands withdrawal!” I heard a frustrated “Merde!” from a guard. The nature of the threat was unclear, but the reaction was not. To break protocol in such a moment was to terminate your career, or worse. We all scattered.

Later, in the relative calm, I sought assessment. The medical officer was brisk. “Assessment: Physically, you are within standard parameters. Psychologically... that falls outside my departmental purview.” He stamped my form. “I find no deficiency in your submitted paperwork.” But his eyes were wary, as if the papers themselves could be revoked at any moment. To have proper papers was to have the right to exist here, a fragile possession indeed.

Exhausted, I finally made my way to the merchant quarter. The armorer took one look at my empty chest—the part of the human torso between the neck and the diaphragm, unprotected by any plating—and advised, “If my inventory is insufficient, you may consult the other registered merchants. Librairie Valois for texts. L'Acier et le Feu for your protective and offensive requisitions.” He gave a grim smile. “A pleasant commune. But solvency is required. Venture beyond the perimeter. Hunt. Or salvage from the ruins.”

I left, the echoes of the day’s warnings and formalities clinging to me. The only certainty

The air in the Préfecture was thick with the matter of bureaucracy—a matter means a vaguely specified concern, and here it was the ceaseless rustle of paper and the low hum of administrative dread. Officer Leclerc watched the citizen at his desk fumble through a dossier.

"My paperwork is still... processing. I'll need a moment to file this properly," the man said, not meeting Leclerc's eyes.

"Did you locate the files?" Leclerc asked, his tone flat.

"The dossier is incomplete. My apologies, my profound apologies."

Leclerc sighed. To feel anything but weary in this place was a rarity; to feel is to undergo an emotional sensation, and his was a constant, low-grade exhaustion. He glanced at his colleague, Sylvain, who was embroiled in his own performance.

"Ah, you again! A pleasure, I'm sure. No time for formalities now; I have a dossier to complete, or did I? Ah, well..." Sylvain announced to no one in particular before spinning to confront an imaginary interrupter. "Syl! You dare interrupt me? Only I interrupt me. As I was just demonstrating."

This was not the military; it was the civil apparatus. Civil means applying to ordinary citizens, a world of stamps and signatures instead of salutes and rifles. Leclerc’s thoughts were interrupted by a senior clerk, who leaned in conspiratorially.

"I heard there's an excellent forger in the 7th Arrondissement," the clerk whispered. "But after thirty years of processing these same forms, watching the same requests denied on technicalities... one learns. The Hexagon doesn't care about your authorization. It cares that you submit."

To submit was to be compliant; to be is to have the quality of existence, and here, existence was validated only by a filed form. The clerk’s voice dropped further. "The reports from the southern préfecture are appalling! Have you seen the communiqué about the incident at the Salon? They're saying the entire curatorial staff has been... eliminated. No one has even filed the proper forms."

A human tragedy reduced to an administrative scandal; human means characteristic of humanity, with all its messy violence and neglect. Leclerc tried to focus on the small discrepancy before him—a small thing, limited in magnitude, yet capable of consuming his entire afternoon.

"I don't know what to make of the Salon affair," the clerk finished, straightening his jacket. "The dossiers just keep piling up, don't they?"

Leclerc looked at the anxious citizen, the performing Sylvain, and the mountain of paper. "Do not fret, my dear," he said, the phrase hollow with habit. "The Préfecture is here to assist." He picked up his stamp, the level of his resolve neither rising nor falling, but holding steady at its familiar, resigned setting. A level is a position on a scale of intensity, and his had been fixed for years. The system endured. One had to appreciate its resilience, even if one could no longer feel it at all.

The air in the Préfecture was a stale mixture of ink, dust, and quiet desperation. Officer Renard’s desk was an island of precarious order, surrounded by a sea of pending files. A comment—which is to say, a whispered personal opinion—from the clerk at the next desk drifted over. “The reports from the southern préfecture are appalling! Have you seen the communiqué about the incident at the Salon?”

Renard didn’t look up from the incomplete dossier before him. “The dossier is incomplete. My apologies, my profound apologies.”

His partner, a weary man named Lefevre, sighed and slid a new form across the desk. “Seventy-two copies. In triplicate. By Friday.” To make copies in this place was to engage in a kind of Sisyphean penance, a ritual more about endurance than productivity.

Their quiet struggle was interrupted by a citizen, a merchant whose face was etched with worry. “Do not fret, my dear. The Préfecture is here to assist,” Renard said, the official mantra feeling hollow even to him.

The merchant leaned in, lowering his voice. “I heard there's an excellent forger in the 7th Arrondissement.”

Lefevre’s head snapped up, but Renard remained impassive. This was not their business; a business is a commercial enterprise, and theirs was the enforcement of order, however Byzantine. “Your papers are revoked!” Lefevre barked, a preemptive strike against any confessed crime.

The merchant paled and scurried away. After a moment, the office intercom chimed, a sound that meant another layer of bureaucratic sediment had been deposited on their day. Lefevre looked at the mountain of files, then at Renard. His voice was grim, determined. “I won't let them transfer you again. I didn't survive three restructurings to lose your file now.”

Renard gave a thin smile. The system’s resilience was, in a perverse way, admirable. “Still, one must appreciate the system's resilience. Even with these... complications, the Republic endures. There's a certain satisfaction in that.”

But satisfaction was fleeting. A commotion erupted by the main doors. The Préfet’s aide was pointing, her voice sharp as a blade. “It's the Renard Gris! You are hereby detained! You should have settled your administrative penalties!”

Renard stood slowly. To leave—to go away from this place—was now an impossibility. He glanced at the canteen door, thinking of the closing hour. “And of course, this means I'll be stuck here through lunch reviewing the discrepancies. The canteen will close before I can file Form 7-B.”

As the guards approached, he understood the final rule of the Préfecture. This was not a game; a game is a contest with rules to determine a winner. Here, the rules themselves were the only victor, and they will—they decree and ordain—that everyone, eventually, loses.

The Préfecture’s waiting room was a big space—big meaning above average in size and extent, filled with the scent of dust and dread. I clutched my papers, the ink still damp. The clerk, a man whose face had settled into permanent bureaucratic resignation, took them without looking at me.

“Assessment: Physically, you are within standard parameters. Psychologically... that falls outside my departmental purview,” he droned. “I find no deficiency in your submitted paperwork.”

I dared to hope. But then his stamp came down like a guillotine. “Your papers are revoked!”

“But why?” I pleaded.

He leaned forward, his voice dropping. “But after thirty years of processing these same forms... one learns. The Hexagon doesn’t care about your authorization. It cares that you submit.” His eyes were hollow. “Submit your papers to the Hexagon. The benefits are... considerable.”

It was clear I needed a new process—a process being a particular course of action intended to achieve a result. I left the Préfecture, the word “submit” ringing in my ears. To leave is to go away from a place, and I did so quickly, heading for the merchant quarter.

At a cluttered stall, I sought advice. The merchant was pragmatic. “If my inventory is insufficient, you may consult the other registered merchants... But solvency is required for a decent standard of living. Venture beyond the perimeter. Hunt.”

“Hunt what?” I asked.

“*Fleur-de-Fer*,” she said. “The alchemists pay well. A moment... your sample manifest appears insufficient. Recall, the minimum requisition for processing is ten specimens.”

This was the key. I would add to my fortunes—to add is to join or combine with others to increase quantity. I spent days in the rust-colored marshes, gathering the metallic blooms. When I returned, filthy but successful, the same merchant nodded. “Again, my thanks for your field assistance. I anticipate your next delivery. And yes, per protocol, the tonic will be ready for collection in twenty-four hours.”

With money—money being the most common medium of exchange—finally in my pocket, I returned to the Préfecture. A different clerk was there now, shredding files with frantic energy.

“The audit is complete. Marianne’s will is done,” she muttered to herself, then noticed me. Her demeanor shifted to one of saccharine concern. “Do not fret, my dear. The Préfecture is here to assist.” But her eyes darted to a fresh communiqué on her desk. “The reports from the southern préfecture are appalling! Have you seen the communiqué about the incident at the Salon? They're saying the entire curatorial staff has been... eliminated. No one has even filed the proper forms.”

She didn’t know what to make of it. “The dossiers just keep piling up, don’t they?” she sighed, before stamping my new papers with a shaky hand.

I emerged into the plaza. The Hexagon’s windows were lit against the twilight. I recalled a whisper from a lamplighter I’d passed days before: “I'm pleas
